choices.text: Inflammation
Ciliary shock
Posterior synechiae
Occlusion of trabecular meshwork

questions.text: A 42-year-old female, presented with sudden onset eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity in her left eye. Examination reveals reduced IOP and anterior chamber inflammation. She is diagnosed with acute iridocyclitis. What is the probable cause of reduced IOP?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ciliary shock

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Inflammation: does not directly affect the intraocular pressure.

 

Option C. Posterior synechiae: Partial occlusion of pupil called seclusio papillae does not intraocular pressure. 360 degrees posterior synechiae cause mechanical pupillary block and raise intraocular pressure due to resultant appositional angle closure due to formation of iris bombae.

 

Option D. Occlusion of trabecular meshwork: Can occur due to clogging of the trabecular meshwork by the intraocular inflammatory cells, leading to secondary open angle glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraocular pressure can be low in cases of intraocular inflammation due to ciliary shock.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Aqueous cells
Keratic precipitates
Hypopyon
Aqueous flare

questions.text: What clinical finding can be demonstrated using the Tyndall effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aqueous flare

 

Option D.

 

Aqueous flare is demonstrated in a fine beam of slit-lamp light as fine moving (Brownian movements) suspended particles. It is based on the Tyndall phenomenon.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aqueous cells: Early sign of iridocyclitis. Cells counted in an oblique slit-lamp beam.

 

Option B. Keratic precipitates: Proteinaceous cellular deposits occurring at the back of cornea. Mostly, these are arranged in a triangular fashion occupying the centre and inferior part of cornea, called Arlt’s triangle due to convection currents in the aqueous humour.

 

 

Option C. Hypopyon: A hypopyon is the accumulation of white blood cells that form a whitish layer of fluid in the lower portion of the eye's anterior chamber. It may be mobile (in uveitis and bacterial keratitis) or immobile (in fungal keratitis).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Students must be able to identify the signs of intraocular inflammation

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Untreated cases can progress to cavernous sinus thrombosis
It involves all three coats of the eyeball
Enucleation is the treatment of choice
Presents with painful limitation of movements

questions.text: Given below are statements regarding panophthalmitis, All are true except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Enucleation is the treatment of choice

 

Option C.

 

  • Panophthalmitis is intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball including tenonâ€™s capsule.

  • Symptoms:

    1. Severe ocular pain with headache

    2. Complete loss of vision

    3. Chemosis and conjunctival congestion

    4. Cloudy and edematous cornea

    5. Pus in anterior chamber

  • Complications include 

    1. Orbital cellulitis

    2. Cavernous sinus thrombosis

    3. Meningitis

    4. Encephalitis

  • Enucleation is contraindicated owing to risk of spread of infection through the dural sheath covering the optic nerve to intracranial space.

  • Evisceration operation should be performed to avoid the risk of intracranial dissemination of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enucleation in contraindicated in panophthalmitis due to risk of intracranial spread of infection via dura mater of the severed optic nerve.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Increased affinity to endothelium in inferior cornea
Convection currents
Increased osmolarity of inflammatory cells
Lipophilic nature of the suspended particles

questions.text: The following finding is noted in a patient. What is the reason behind this pattern of deposition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Convection currents

 

Option B.

 

  • The given picture shows deposition of keratic precipitates in the form of a Arlt’s triangle.
  • The pattern of deposition of KP’s occurs due to convection currents.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Increased affinity of endothelium:  The nutrition of the corneal endothelium becomes affected in uveitis so that the cells become sticky and may desquamate in places. The exudates tend to stick there, forming keratic precipitates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Convection currents in the eye cause deposition of keratic precipitates in an Arlt’s triangle configuration.

 

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Timolol
Dorzolamide
Latanoprost
Brimonidine

questions.text: A 29-year-old female patient, who is a known case of uveitis, came to the OPD with complaints of headache and ocular pain. After thorough examination, she was diagnosed with secondary open angle glaucoma. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Latanoprost

 

Option C.

 

  • One of the complications of uveitis is inflammatory glaucoma / Hypertensive uveitis.
  • Drugs contraindicated in hypertensive uveitis include:
  1. Pilocarpine
  2. Prostaglandin analogues
  • These drugs cause exacerbation of uveitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. TIMOLOL: It is a non selective beta blocker and is contraindicated in patients with history of asthma. Beta-1 selective beta blocker Betaxolol is used in patients with asthma and COPD

 

Option B. DORZOLAMIDE: It is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor. It inhibits the function of corneal endothelial cells and is relatively contraindicated in patients with endothelial dysfunction.

 

Option C. BRIMONIDINE: It is a alpha agonist. It has CNS suppressant effect and may cause somnolence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pilocarpine and Prosyaglandin analogues increase intraocular inflammation.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Bridging vessels noted in angle
Heterochromia
Non granulomatous anterior uveitis
Iris nodules

questions.text: A young male patient with unilateral mature cataract during preop evaluation was found to have stellate keratic precipitates. The following are features of the underlying condition except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iris nodules

 

Option D.

 

  • The diagnosis is Fuchs’ uveitis syndrome.
  • It is a chronic non-granulomatous type of low-grade anterior uveitis.
  • Features include:
  1. Early cataract formation
  2. Heterochromia
  3. Diffuse stromal iris atrophy (Moth eaten appearance)
  4. Fine stellate KPs (exception to Arlt triangle, these KPs are diffusely distributed)
  5. Faint aqueous flare
  6. Fine vessels in angle of Anterior chamber which bleeds during paracentesis – Amsler’s sign

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bridging Vessels Noted in Angle: This is a feature of FHI. Fine blood vessels, known as bridging vessels or iris angiogenesis, can cross the anterior chamber angle in FHI, which is an abnormal finding.

 

Option B. Heterochromia: Heterochromia, a difference in color between the two irises, is a classic sign of FHI. It's typically subtle and may not always be easily noticeable.

 

Option C. Non-Granulomatous Anterior Uveitis: FHI typically presents as a chronic, mild, anterior uveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Unlike other forms of anterior uveitis, iris nodules (Koeppe and Busacca nodules) are typically absent in FHI. This is one of the distinguishing features that sets FHI apart from other types of uveitis.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of eye

choices.text: Irideremia
Corectopia
Coloboma
Polycoria

questions.text: Identify.?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Coloboma

 

Option C.

 

  • The picture is suggestive of congenital coloboma of iris. Cause: Defective closure of embryonic fissure

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Irideremia: Irideremia, also known as aniridia, is a congenital condition characterized by the complete or partial absence of the iris, often associated with vision problems and light sensitivity.

 

 

Option B. Corectopia: Corectopia refers to a displacement or misalignment of the pupil from its normal, central position, often occurring as a result of trauma, surgery, or congenital anomalies.

 

 

Option D. Polycoria: Polycoria is a rare condition where there are apparent multiple pupils in the eye, often due to iris defects or additional openings within the iris.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A coloboma is a congenital defect where normal tissue in or around the eye is missing, often affecting the iris, retina, choroid, or optic nerve, and can appear as a keyhole or notch in the affected structure.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Ring synechiae
Segmental posterior synechiae
Iris edema
Contraction of fibrinous exudate over iris

questions.text: What is the reason behind this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Segmental posterior synechiae

 

Option B.

 

  • The given picture is of a festooned pupil.
  • Reason: The segmental posterior synechiae causes irregular appearance on dilatation.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ring Synechiae: Ring synechiae, also known as annular synechiae, involve the adhesion of the entire pupillary margin to the lens, forming a continuous ring. This condition can lead to pupil deformation, but it typically results in a more fixed and circular shape rather than a festooned appearance.

 

Option C. Iris Edema: While iris edema can alter the appearance of the iris, it generally does not cause a festooned pupil. Edema typically leads to a diffusely swollen and thickened iris rather than specific alterations in pupil shape.

 

Option D. Contraction of Fibrinous Exudate Over Iris: The contraction of fibrinous exudates, which can occur in cases of severe anterior uveitis or after intraocular surgery, can lead to irregularities in the pupil shape.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Segmental posterior synechiae refer to localized adhesions of the iris to the lens. These can lead to an irregular pupil shape as portions of the pupil margin are anchored, while others are not, potentially resulting in a festooned appearance.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Neural crest cells
Ectoderm
Mesoderm
Endoderm

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient came to the ophthalmologist for a routine check-up. On fundoscopy, an elevated pigmented oval mass was noticed. What is the likely origin of this mass?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neural crest cells.

 

Option A:

 

An elevated pigmented mass on fundus evaluation is most likely due to malignant melanoma of choroid.

 

  • It arises from neural crest derived uveal pigment cells.
  • Most common primary intraocular tumor in adults.
  • Symptoms are often absent; it is detected by chance.
  • A dome-shaped mass and clumps of overlying orange pigment are common.

 

Collar stud tumor – growth of pigmented mass through ruptured Bruch membrane.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ectoderm: The ectoderm itself primarily gives rise to the outer layer of skin, the central and peripheral nervous systems, and the eyes.

 

Option C. Mesoderm: The mesoderm forms muscles, bones, the circulatory system, and internal organs, but not melanocytes.

 

Option D. Endoderm: The endoderm forms the lining of the digestive and respiratory systems, and other internal organs, but not melanocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Melanocytes are derived form neuralcrest cells.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Vancomycin
Ceftazidime
Voriconazole
Gentamycin

questions.text: All the following can be administered through an intravitreal route except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gentamycin

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vancomycin: Vancomycin can be administered intravitreally, particularly for the treatment of bacterial endophthalmitis caused by gram-positive bacteria.

 

Option B. Ceftazidime: Ceftazidime is also used intravitreally, especially for treating bacterial endophthalmitis caused by gram-negative bacteria.

 

Option C. Voriconazole: Voriconazole, an antifungal medication, can be administered intravitreally for fungal infections of the eye, such as fungal endophthalmitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Out of the following drugs, Gentamycin is avoided for intravitreal injection because of its increased risk of retinotoxicity (leads to MACULAR INFARCTION).

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Toxoplasmosis
Cysticercosis
Toxocariasis
Histoplasmosis

questions.text: What is the given fundus picture suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cysticercosis

 

Option B:

 

  • The given fundus picture shows subretinal cyst with overlying retinal detachment – suggestive of ocular cysticercosis.
  • Caused by Cysticercus cellulosae, the larval form of the pork tapeworm Taenia solium.
  • Management – surgical removal of larvae undercover of steroids to control inflammation and anti-helminthic drugs for systemic disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Toxoplasmosis: Retinochoroidal scar seen in congenital infection. “Headlight in fog” appeared due to chorioretinitis.

 

 

Option C. Toxocariasis: Chronic endophthalmitis presenting with leukocoria. Posterior pole or peripheral granuloma also may be seen.

 

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: Histospots (atrophic spots in retina) and Macular histospots (atrophic macular scar) noted on fundoscopy.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fundus picture shows subretinal cyst with overlying retinal detachment – suggestive of ocular cysticercosis.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Retinal detachment
Pigment epithelium detachment
Choroidal detachment
Posterior vitreous detachment

questions.text: Identify the finding shown in the B scan image given below.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Choroidal detachment

 

Option C:

 

  • This is a B scan picture showing convex smooth elevation with immobile thick line located anterior to the equator suggestive of choroidal detachment.
  • Choroidal detachment – separation of choroid from sclera.
  • The anterior chamber is shallow.
  • On ophthalmoscopic examination the detached choroid is seen through the pupil as a dark brown mass.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Retinal Detachment: The RD is attached to the Optic Disc.

 

 

Option B: Pigment epithelial defect: It is not appreciated on B-Scan but seen on Optical Coherence Tomography.

 

 

Option D: Posterior Vitreous Detachment.: On B-Scan ultrasound, PVD is differentiated from RD by its separation from the optic disc, aftermovements and disappearance on reducing the gain of the scan.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Choroidal detachments are dome shaped.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of the eye 22nd edition

choices.text: Internal limiting membrane
Bruch membrane
Descemet’s membrane
External limiting membrane

questions.text: Lamina vitrea is also known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bruch membrane

 

Option B:

 

  • The choroid is covered by a thin elastic membrane, the lamina vitrea, also known as the Bruch’s membrane.
  • It lines the layer of choriocapillaris.
  • It lies in approximation with the pigment epithelium of the retina.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. INTERNAL LIMITING MEMBRANE: The internal limiting membrane (ILM) is the innermost layer of the retina:

 

  1. Anatomical Barrier: The ILM forms a barrier between the vitreous humor and the retinal nerve fiber layer. It helps maintain the structural integrity of the retina and separates retinal cells from the vitreous body.
  2. Support for Retinal Cells: It provides physical support to the retinal cells, particularly the Müller cells, which are essential for the normal functioning of the retina.
  3. Role in Eye Diseases: The ILM is involved in various retinal diseases. In conditions like macular holes and epiretinal membranes, changes in the ILM can lead to vision impairment.
  4. Surgical Importance: During vitrectomy, the ILM is often peeled away to relieve traction or to remove epiretinal membranes.
  5. Oxygen and Nutrient Diffusion: While the ILM acts as a barrier, it also allows for the diffusion of essential nutrients and oxygen from the vitreous body to the retina, thereby playing a role in the metabolic exchanges necessary for retinal health.
  6. Growth Factor Regulation: The ILM may have a role in regulating the availability of growth factors to the retina, which is important for retinal development and repair.

 

The ILM's integrity is crucial for maintaining retinal structure and function. Its role becomes particularly significant in various retinal surgical procedures and in the management of retinal diseases.

 

Option C. DESCEMET’S MEMBRANE:

 

  1. Location and Structure: Descemet's membrane is located between the stroma and the endothelial layer of the cornea. It's a thin, clear layer composed of collagen and other fibers.
  2. Function: This membrane serves as a protective barrier for the corneal endothelium and plays a critical role in maintaining corneal hydration and transparency.
  3. Development and Growth: Descemet's membrane is unique in that it continues to grow throughout a person's life. The membrane is thicker in older individuals compared to younger ones.
  4. Role in Eye Health: Descemet's membrane is crucial for corneal health. Descemet’s membrane detachment or disease affecting can lead to endothelial cell failure with resultant corneal edema, corneal decompensation and vision impairment.
  5. Surgical Importance: In certain corneal surgeries, such as lamellar corneal transplants or endothelial keratoplasty, Descemet's membrane is a focal point. DSEK (Descemets stripping endothelial keratoplasty) is performed for treatment of Fuch’s dystrophy.
  6. Regeneration Capabilities: Unlike other parts of the cornea, Descemet's membrane has limited regenerative capabilities. If damaged, it doesn't repair or regenerate as effectively as the epithelial layer of the cornea.
  7. Clinical Significance: Various corneal diseases, such as keratoconus or endothelial dystrophies, can manifest changes in Descemet's membrane, making its examination important in diagnosing these conditions.

 

Option D. EXTERNAL LIMITING MEMBRANE:

 

  1. Location and Composition: The ELM is located within the retina, situated between the inner segments of the photoreceptor cells (rods and cones) and the outer nuclear layer, which contains the cell bodies of the photoreceptors.
  2. Structure: It is not a true membrane but rather a series of junctions—specifically, adherens junctions—between Müller cells and the photoreceptor cells. These junctions appear as a line when viewed under a microscope, hence the term "membrane."
  3. Role in Retinal Integrity: The ELM plays a crucial role in maintaining the structural integrity of the retina. It helps to organize and stabilize the arrangement of photoreceptor cells.
  4. Barrier Function: While it allows for the passage of nutrients and waste products, the ELM also serves as a barrier to larger molecules, thereby protecting the photoreceptor layer.
  5. Indication of Retinal Health: In various retinal imaging techniques, such as Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT), the integrity of the ELM is often assessed as an indicator of retinal health. Disruption or irregularity in the ELM can be a sign of retinal diseases or damage.
  6. Role in Disease: Changes or damage to the ELM can be involved in various retinal diseases, diabetic retinopathy, and retinal detachment. These conditions can lead to impaired vision or blindness.
  7. Regenerative Potential: Unlike some other parts of the retina, the ELM has limited regenerative capacity. Damage to this area can have lasting effects on vision.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lamina vitrea/bruch’s membrane, external limiting membrane and internal limiting membrane are important structural layers of the retina.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of the eye 22nd edition

choices.text: Herpes simplex
Tuberculosis
Reiter syndrome
Sarcoidosis

questions.text: A 37-year-old male presented with mild ocular redness for the past 4 months. On examination, he had large keratic precipitates with minimal flare. The likely etiology for this condition includes all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reiter syndrome

 

Option C.

 

  • The given case scenario is suggestive of granulomatous uveitis.

  • It is characterized by the presence of large, greasy â€˜mutton fatâ€™ keratic precipitates which are deposits of white blood cells (Mainly lymphocytes) derived from the aqueous on the corneal endothelium.

  • It has a chronic presentation with quiescent inflammatory reaction.

  • Differentials of granulomatous uveitis include:

 

  1. TB

  2. Syphilis

  3. Sarcoidosis

  4. VKH

  5. Sympathetic ophthalmitis

  6. Leptospirosis

  7. HSV

 

Explanation:

 

Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is a type of inflammatory arthritis that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body, often the intestines, genitals, or urinary tract. It is classified as a form of spondyloarthritis, which is a group of joint diseases that specifically affect the spine and the areas where the tendons and ligaments attach to bones.

 

The key features of Reiter's syndrome include:

 

  1. Arthritis: Swelling, pain, and stiffness of the joints, especially the knees, ankles, and feet. It can also affect the fingers, wrists, elbows, and spine.

  2. Urethritis: Inflammation of the urethra, which can cause pain during urination and an increased urge to urinate.

  3. Conjunctivitis: Inflammation of the lining of the eye, leading to redness, irritation, and discomfort.

  4. Enthesitis: Inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone, particularly at the heels, toes, or spine.

  5. Skin and Mucous Membrane Lesions: Some people may develop skin rashes, sores in the mouth, or keratoderma blennorrhagica (small, painless, hard nodules on the palms and soles).

 

The exact cause of Reiter's syndrome is not known, but it is believed to be triggered by certain bacterial infections. Commonly implicated bacteria include Chlamydia trachomatis, which is sexually transmitted, and certain gastrointestinal bacteria like Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, and Campylobacter.

 

The treatment of Reiter's syndrome focuses on relieving symptoms and includes the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), corticosteroids, and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). Antibiotics may be used if a bacterial infection is identified as the trigger. Additionally, physical therapy can help maintain joint function and range of motion.

 

Most people with Reiter's syndrome recover fully from the initial episode within 12 months, but some may experience chronic arthritis or recurrent episodes of the disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

By analyzing the case of a 37-year-old male with chronic ocular redness and identifying the presence of large keratic precipitates with minimal flare,the diagnosis is  granulomatous anterior uveitis. Cause of this clinical picture are Herpes simplex, Tuberculosis, and Sarcoidosis. Reiter's syndrome, also known as reactive arthritis, is the classic triad of conjunctivitis, urethritis, and arthritis occurring after an infection, particularly those in the urogenital or gastrointestinal tract.

 

Ref: Parsonâ€™s diseases of the eye 22nd edition

questions.solution:
Ans. D) A3, B1, C2

 

Option D.

Fine KPs are seen in Non-granulomatous uveitis, Mutton Fat KPs in granulomatous uveitis and Stellate KPs in Fuchâ€™s uveitis.

choices.text: Pupillary miosis
Aqueous reaction
Posterior synechiae
Iris neovascularization

questions.text: The given finding predisposes to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior synechiae

 

Option C.

 

  • The given picture shows Koeppe’s nodules located at the pupillary border.

 

These are sites of posterior synechiae formation.

 

 

Posterior Syneciae are adhesions between the iris and the anterior lens capsule.

 

Pupils with posterior synechiae have a festooned pupil appearance.

Eye with 360 degrees posterior synechiae can undergo pupillary block glaucoma a configuration called iris bombe or occlusio pupillae.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. AQUEOUS REACTION: In cases of intraocular inflammation, inflammatory cells and flare can be seen on slit lamp examination. This is called aqueous reaction.

 

Option D. Iris neovascularization refers to the abnormal growth of new blood vessels on the iris. This condition is typically a secondary response to other ocular or systemic conditions that cause reduced blood flow or oxygenation to the retina. Here's a detailed explanation:

 

  1. Causes: Iris neovascularization is often a result of ischemic conditions within the eye, Common causes include diabetic retinopathy, retinal vein occlusion, uveitis, and ischemic central retinal artery occlusion. Systemic diseases like diabetes mellitus and hypertension can also contribute to its development.
  2. Pathophysiology: In response to retinal ischemia (lack of blood flow), the body releases growth factors like vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). These factors stimulate the growth of new blood vessels in an attempt to increase blood supply. However, these new vessels are often weak, leaky, and can grow in inappropriate areas like the iris and the angle of the anterior chamber of the eye.
  3. Symptoms and Complications: Initially, iris neovascularization may not cause any symptoms. As it progresses, it can lead to complications like neovascular glaucoma, a severe form of glaucoma with high intraocular pressure due to the blockage of the eye’s drainage system by the new vessels. Symptoms may include pain, redness, blurred vision, and vision loss.
  4. Diagnosis: It is diagnosed by slit-lamp examination and gonioscopy. Fluorescein angiography may also be used to highlight blood flow in the retina and iris.
  5. Treatment: Treatment focuses on managing the underlying cause and preventing complications. Laser therapy, such as panretinal photocoagulation (PRP), can reduce the drive for neovascularization by treating retinal ischemia. Intravitreal injections of anti-VEGF medications directly into the eye can also help by inhibiting the growth factors responsible for the formation of new blood vessels. In advanced cases, surgery may be necessary to manage complications like neovascular glaucoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Koeppe’s nodules occurring at the pupillary margin lead to formation of posterior synechiae.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of eye 22nd edition

choices.text: Atropine
Procaine
Dexamethasone
Adrenaline

questions.text: Injection mydricaine is composed of all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dexamethasone

 

Option C.

 

  • Mydricaine is a preparation containing adrenaline, atropine and anesthetic agents.
  • It is used to try to break fresh posterior synechiae when drops are ineffective.
  • Constituent quantities are 0.3 ml containing 0.12 mg adrenaline, 1 mg atropine and 6 mg procaine. These quantities vary according to the manufacturer.
  • It is usually administered by subconjunctival injection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Atropine: Atropine is a muscarinic antagonist that causes dilation of the pupil (mydriasis) and is commonly included in mydricaine preparations.

 

Option B. Procaine: Procaine is a local anesthetic agent that may be included in the mixture to provide anesthesia to the eye during surgery.

 

Option D. Adrenaline: Adrenaline (epinephrine) is often included for its vasoconstrictive properties, which help to prolong the effect of local anesthetics and to control intraocular bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Steroid injection are not a composition of mydricaine , as these are designed primarily for mydriasis and anesthesia.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Extract immediately
Wait for at least 3 months after settling of inflammation
Observation with no intervention
Wait for 1 year

questions.text: A 32-year-old male was diagnosed with chronic uveitis and is currently on treatment for the same. He visited the ophthalmologist with complaints of reduced vision and the following eye finding is observed. What is the next step to be taken?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wait for at least 3 months after settling off inflammation

 

Option B:

 

  • The given picture shows a festooned pupil with cataractous lens. Cataract occurring secondary to some other intraocular disease (like uveitis in this case) is known as Complicated cataract.
  • In such a condition, it is advisable to extract cataract after the uveitis has been quiescent for at least 2–3 months.
  • Heparin coated IOL is beneficial in preventing postoperative inflammation in complicated cataract due to uveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cataract surgery in cases of uveitis must be done after at least 3 months of quiescence of inflammatory activity.

 

Ref: Parson’s diseases of the eye 22nd edition

choices.text: Posner-Schlossman syndrome
Uveal effusion syndrome
Acute congestive glaucoma
Pseudoexfoliation syndrome

questions.text: A young adult with a history of recurring episodes of sudden increased intraocular pressure. On evaluation, fine keratic precipitates, corneal edema, and a dilated pupil are noted in the left eye. The depth of the anterior chamber appears normal. Based on these findings, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posner-Schlossman syndrome

 

Option A:

 

Posner-Schlossman syndrome is characterized by:

 

  1. Recurrent unilateral attacks of acute rise of IOP (40-50mmHg) without shallow anterior chamber
  2. Fine KPs without posterior synechiae
  3. Corneal edema
  4. Dilated pupil
  5. No congestion (white eye)

 

Also known as Glaucomatocyclitic crisis

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Uveal effusion syndrome:

 

  • Features:
    • Idiopathic choroidal detachment.
    • Ciliochoroidal detachment followed by exudative retinal detachment.
    • Usually in middle-aged hypermetropic men.
    • Inflammation is absent or mild. 
    • Low IOP is common.
    • Shallow AC may be seen.
    • After resolution, a characteristic retinal ‘leopard spot’ mottling is seen.

 

Option C. Acute congestive glaucoma:

 

  • Features:
    • Presents acute severe pain in the eye.
    • Congested conjunctiva.
    • Shallow AC closed angle is seen.
    • Aqueous flare or cells may be present.
    • IOP is raised.
    • The pupil is semi-dilated, vertically oval and fixed.

 

Option D. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome:

 

  • Features:
    • Deposition of an amorphous grey dandruff-like material on the structures in anterior segment.
    • Presents as glaucoma- open angle or closed angle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young adult presenting with recurring episodes of sudden increased intraocular pressure, fine keratic precipitates, corneal edema, dilated pupil, and a normal anterior chamber depth, the likely diagnosis is Posner-Schlossman Syndrome, characterized by unilateral, recurrent elevated intraocular pressure and mild anterior uveitis.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Circular fibers are located in the outer part of ciliary body
Circular fibres are involved in accommodation
Supply is by sympathetic fibres through short ciliary nerve
Meridional fibres help in aqueous outflow

questions.text: All are true regarding ciliary muscles except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supply is by sympathetic fibres through short ciliary nerve

 

Option C:
 

CILIARY MUSCLES:

 

Nerve supply: parasympathetic fibres through short ciliary nerve

 

Explanation

 

Option A: Circular fibers are Located in the Inner Part of Ciliary Body: This statement is true. The circular fibers of the ciliary muscle is located in the inner part of the ciliary body,

 

 

Option B: Circular Fibres are Involved in Accommodation: This is true. The circular (or sphincter) fibers of the ciliary muscle contract during accommodation, allowing the lens to become more convex and focus on near objects.

 

Option D: Meridional Fibres Help in Aqueous Outflow: This is true. The meridional (or longitudinal) fibers of the ciliary muscle, when contracted, put tension on the trabecular meshwork, facilitating the outflow of aqueous humor from the anterior chamber and thus helping to regulate intraocular pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ciliary muscle is primarily innervated by parasympathetic fibers from the oculomotor nerve (CN III), not sympathetic fibers. The parasympathetic innervation causes the muscle to contract, aiding in accommodation.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Anterior polar cataract
Posterior subcapsular cataract
Nuclear cataract
Posterior polar cataract

questions.text: What type of complicated cataract is seen in uveitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior subcapsular cataract

 

Option B.

 

  • The complicated cataract in uveitis is posterior subcapsular cortical cataract.
  • In the beam of the slit lamp, the opacities have an appearance like breadcrumbs and a characteristic rainbow display of colours often replaces the normal achromatic sheen (polychromatic lustre).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior Polar Cataract: This type of cataract forms at the front of the lens and is typically congenital or associated with trauma, not typically with uveitis.

 

Option C. Nuclear Cataract: This type forms in the central nucleus of the lens and is most commonly associated with aging.

 

Option D. Posterior Polar Cataract: Like anterior polar cataracts, posterior polar cataracts form at the back of the lens but are typically congenital and not commonly associated with uveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cataract associated with uveiti is Posterior Subcapsular Cataract.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Dexamethasone eye drops
Moxifloxacin eye drops
Homatropine eye drops
Pilocarpine eye drops

questions.text: A 23-year-old sportsman had an accidental injury to his left eye with a rubber ball. On evaluation, circumcorneal congestion and the presence of 2+ cells in the anterior chamber are noted. The following drugs are indicated for his treatment, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pilocarpine eye drops

 

 

  • The given case scenario is of traumatic anterior uveitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone Eye Drops: These are corticosteroid eye drops used to reduce inflammation in the eye. In cases of traumatic eye injuries with inflammatory responses, such as anterior uveitis (indicated by cells in the anterior chamber), steroids like dexamethasone are often used.

 

Option B. Moxifloxacin Eye Drops: Moxifloxacin is an antibiotic eye drop. In cases of eye trauma, antibiotic eye drops may be used prophylactically to prevent bacterial infections, even if there is no initial sign of infection.

 

Option C. Homatropine Eye Drops: Homatropine is an anticholinergic agent used as a cycloplegic and mydriatic. It dilates the pupil and paralyzes the ciliary muscle, providing pain relief in inflammatory conditions of the eye like traumatic uveitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the case of a traumatic eye injury with signs of inflammation, treatment should include anti-inflammatory agents (like dexamethasone), antibiotics for infection prophylaxis (like moxifloxacin), and cycloplegics for pain relief (like homatropine). Pilocarpine, a miotic agent, is not indicated in this scenario due to its potential to exacerbate inflammation and pain.

 

Ref:  Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Mesoderm
Surface ectoderm
Neuroectoderm
Endoderm

questions.text: Where do the muscles of iris develop from?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuroectoderm

 

Option C.

 

The intrinsic muscles of the iris (sphincter pupillae and dilator pupillae) are derived from the surrounding neuroectoderm, whereas the ciliary muscle, the structure eventually responsible for changing the shape of the mature lens, is derived from invading neural crest cells

 

  • Iris epithelial layers are derived from the marginal region of optic cup â€“ neuroectoderm.

  • Sphincter and dilator pupillae are derived from anterior epithelium which has neuroectodermal origin.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mesoderm: While the mesoderm contributes to many structures in the eye, such as the sclera and vascular components, it does not give rise to the muscles of the iris.

 

Option B. Surface Ectoderm: The surface ectoderm forms structures like the lens of the eye and the corneal epithelium, but not the iris muscles.

 

Option D. Endoderm: The endoderm primarily forms the internal organs like the gastrointestinal tract, lungs, and liver, and is not involved in the development of the eye's structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iris muscles develop from neuroectoderm.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Cyclodialysis
Iridodonesis
Iridoschisis
Iridodialysis

questions.text: Following a history of blunt ocular trauma, a young male patient underwent an anterior segment evaluation that unveiled a distinct finding. What is this particular presentation commonly referred to as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iridodialysis

 

Option D.

 

  • The given picture is characterized by a D shaped pupil with a black biconvex area in the periphery – seen in iridodialysis.
  • It refers to detachment of iris from its root at the ciliary body.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cyclodialysis is separation of longitudinal ciliary muscle fibers from scleral spur.

 

Option B. Iridodonesis is the trembling of iris, seen due to subluxation of lens.

 

Option C. Iridoschisis refers to splitting of layers of iris stroma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Peripheral detachment of the iris is called iridodialysis.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Quiet anterior chamber
Most common presentation is reduced vision
Posteriorly choroiditis may be present
Symptoms include pain, redness and photophobia

questions.text: All the statements about posterior uveitis given below are correct, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Symptoms include pain, redness and photophobia

 

Option D.

 

  • Posterior uveitis – inflammation of the choroid (choroiditis) and in most cases, associated with retinitis (chorioretinitis).
  • Choroiditis is a painless condition.
  • Presentation – visual symptoms due to associated vitreous haze (floaters).
  • No external signs and the eye looks quiet.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Quiet Anterior Chamber: This is typically true for posterior uveitis. Since the inflammation primarily affects the back of the eye, the anterior chamber often appears quiet or without significant inflammation.

 

Option B. Most Common Presentation is Reduced Vision: This is correct. Reduced vision is a common symptom of posterior uveitis due to the involvement of the retina and choroid.

 

Option C. Posteriorly Choroiditis May Be Present: This statement is also true.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Uveitis does not present with pain, redness and photophobia.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Eye becomes shrunken and soft
Disorganization of ciliary body
Increased aqueous production
It is an end-stage of chronic uveitis

questions.text: All are true regarding the given condition except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased aqueous production

 

Option C.

 

  • The given picture is diagnostic of phthisis bulbi.
  • It is the final stage of chronic uveitis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Eye Becomes Shrunken and Soft: This is true. In phthisis bulbi, the eye undergoes atrophy and shrinkage, becoming soft and often smaller than normal.

 

Option B. Disorganization of Ciliary Body: This is also true. Phthisis bulbi involves disorganization and atrophy of the internal structures of the eye, including the ciliary body.

 

Option D. It is an End-Stage of Chronic Uveitis: This is true. Phthisis bulbi can be the end-stage of various ocular diseases, including chronic uveitis, severe eye injury, or other chronic eye diseases that lead to irreversible damage and atrophy of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phthisis bulbi is typically associated with decreased aqueous production due to the disorganization and atrophy of the ciliary body, which is responsible for aqueous humor production. The condition often leads to hypotony.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: AV fistula
Microphthalmos
Posterior scleritis
Excessive laser treatment

questions.text: Differentials for uveal effusion syndrome are all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microphthalmos

 

Option B.

 

THE PATHOGENESIS OF UVEAL EFFUSION SYNDROME

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. AV Fistula: An arteriovenous (AV) fistula, particularly an orbital or cavernous sinus fistula, can lead to increased venous pressure, which might result in effusions in the eye.

 

Option C. Posterior Scleritis: Posterior scleritis is an inflammation of the sclera (the white outer layer of the eye) that can present similarly to uveal effusion syndrome, with pain, redness, and potential serous retinal detachment.

 

Option D. Excessive Laser Treatment: Excessive laser treatment, particularly in the context of retinal procedures, can lead to complications including inflammation, hemorrhage, and uveal effusions. It can be a differential diagnosis for uveal effusion syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Microphthalmos refers to a smaller-than-normal eye and is a developmental anomaly. It is not typically associated with the presentation of uveal effusion syndrome and therefore is not a differential diagnosis for it.

choices.text: Anterior uveitis
Panophthalmitis
Central corneal ulcer
Endophthalmitis

questions.text: Identify the given picture.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Panophthalmitis

 

Option B.

 

  • The given picture demonstrates lid edema, conjunctival congestion and chemosis with corneal melt suggestive of panophthalmitis.
  • Cause – Acute bacterial infection.
  • It is the intense purulent inflammation of all coats of the eyeball.
  • Treatment – Evisceration to avoid intracranial spread.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Anterior Uveitis: Anterior uveitis is an inflammation of the anterior segment of the uveal tract, primarily affecting the iris and ciliary body, and is characterized by eye redness, pain, photophobia, and potential vision loss.

 

Option C. Central Corneal Ulcer: A central corneal ulcer is an inflammatory or infective condition of the cornea involving its central part, causing pain, redness, blurred vision, and discharge.

 

Option D. Endophthalmitis: Endophthalmitis is a severe inflammation of the internal structures of the eye, often caused by infection, which can lead to rapid vision loss if not treated promptly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given picture demonstrates lid edema, conjunctival congestion and chemosis with corneal melt suggestive of panophthalmitis.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Males are more commonly affected than females
Bilateral presentation
Presence of pseudopolycoria
There occurs development of posterior synechiae

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding essential iris atrophy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of pseudopolycoria

 

Option C:

 

Progressive (essential) iris atrophy is characterized by iris changes including:

 

  • Corectopia (pupil malposition)
  • Iris atrophy in the early stage
  • Pseudopolycoria (supernumerary false pupil)
  • Broad-based peripheral anterior synechiae that often extend anterior to the schwalbe line
  • Severe iris atrophy in the late stage, associated with ectropion uveae and severe glaucoma.

 

 

  • This is a rare, idiopathic condition.
  • Unilateral progressive atrophy of iris.
  • Affects young females > males.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Males are more commonly affected than females: This is incorrect. Essential iris atrophy, like other forms of ICE syndrome, is more commonly seen in females.

 

Option B. Bilateral Presentation: Essential iris atrophy typically presents unilaterally, not bilaterally. While it can rarely affect both eyes, it usually does so to a varying degree.

 

Option D. There occurs development of posterior synechiae: Posterior synechiae, which are adhesions between the iris and the lens, are not a typical feature of essential iris atrophy.

The hallmark of this condition is atrophy and distortion of the iris tissue, rather than the formation of adhesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There is presence of pseudopolycoria in essential iris atrophy.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Intraocular malignancy
Bleeding anterior staphyloma
Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage
Panophthalmitis

questions.text: Indications for evisceration includes all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intraocular malignancy

 

Option A:

 

  • Evisceration involves removal of all contents of eyeball leaving behind the sclera.
  • Indications
  1. Panophthalmitis
  2. Bleeding anterior staphyloma
  3. Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Bleeding Anterior Staphyloma: This can be an indication for evisceration. Anterior staphyloma is a bulging of the cornea and sclera due to thinning, and if it leads to complications like bleeding, evisceration might be considered.

 

Option C. Expulsive Choroidal Hemorrhage: This is a severe complication of intraocular surgeries and can be an indication for evisceration. It occurs when there is a rupture in the choroidal blood vessels, leading to a massive hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Panophthalmitis: Panophthalmitis, a severe and extensive inflammation of the entire eyeball, can be an indication for evisceration, especially when there is no visual potential in the eye and the aim is to alleviate pain and reduce the risk of systemic spread of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Evisceration is contraindicated in cases of intraocular malignancy, such as choroidal melanoma, because of the risk of spreading malignant cells. Enucleation (removal of the entire eyeball) is the preferred procedure in such cases.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Waardenburg syndrome
Ocular siderosis
Sturge weber syndrome
Oculodermal melanocytosis

questions.text: Causes of Hyperchromic heterochromia iridis are all, except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Waardenburg syndrome

 

Option A:

 

All the options given cause hyperchromic heterochromia iridis, except Waardenburg syndrome which causes hypochromic heterochromia iridis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ocular Siderosis: Ocular siderosis is a condition caused by the deposition of iron in the eye, usually following a penetrating eye injury with an iron-containing foreign body. It can lead to a darker iris in the affected eye, thus causing heterochromia.

 

Option C. Sturge-Weber Syndrome: Sturge-Weber syndrome is not typically associated with heterochromia iridis. It's characterized by a port-wine stain on the face and may involve ocular and neurological abnormalities,

 

Option D. Oculodermal Melanocytosis: Also known as Nevus of Ota, it is a congenital condition characterized by hyperpigmentation of the eye and surrounding skin, which can cause hyperchromic heterochromia due to increased pigmentation in one iris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Waardenburg syndrome is a cause of Hypochromic Heterochromia Iriditis.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Intravitreal vancomycin + ceftazidime
Pars plana vitrectomy
Systemic antibiotics
Evisceration

questions.text: A patient with septicemia had the following ocular finding. The visual acuity of this eye is 6/60. What is the first line of treatment for the ocular pathology in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intravitreal vancomycin + ceftazidime

 

Option A:

 

  • The given picture shows ciliary congestion with hypopyon in the anterior chamber. This kind of presentation in the given scenario is suggestive of endogenous endophthalmitis.
  • The first line in treatment of endophthalmitis depends on visual acuity at presentation (Endophthalmitis vitrectomy study):

 

  

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient postoperative endophthalmitis with vision of 6/60 or better, intravitreal antibiotics is the first line of treatment.

 

Ref: Results of the Endophthalmitis Vitrectomy Study. A randomized trial of immediate vitrectomy and of intravenous antibiotics for the treatment of postoperative bacterial endophthalmitis. Endophthalmitis Vitrectomy Study Group. Arch Ophthalmol. 1995 Dec;113(12):1479-96. PMID: 7487614.

choices.text: Choroidal melanoma
Choroidal hemangioma
Choroidal osteoma
Choroidal melanocytoma

questions.text: A 9-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with a complaint of seizure. A port-wine stain birthmark involving the forehead and upper right eyelid was noticed. After conducting a thorough clinical examination and imaging studies, the baby is diagnosed with Sturge-Weber syndrome. What is it associated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Choroidal hemangioma

 

Option B:

 

  • Sturge Weber syndrome (encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis)- congenital, sporadic phacomatosis.
  • FEATURES:
    • Nevus flammeus (Port wine stain) – unilateral (along the distribution of trigeminal nerve)
    • Leptomeningeal hemangioma- ipsilateral parietal or occipital region may cause contralateral focal or generalized seizures, hemiparesis or hemianopia.
    • Diffuse Choroidal hemangioma – diffuse deep red discoloration of fundus
    • Congenital glaucoma (ipsilateral)
    • Episcleral haemangioma
    • Iris heterochromia

 

The other options are not typically associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Choroidal Melanoma: This is a malignant tumor of the eye and is not associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

 

 

Option C. Choroidal Osteoma: This is a rare, benign tumor involving the formation of bone-like tissue in the choroid, which is not linked to Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

 

Option D. Choroidal Melanocytoma: This is a benign pigmented tumor of the choroid, also not typically associated with Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sturge weber syndrome is associated with choroidal hemangioma.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Keratic precipitates
Anterior chamber cells
Posterior synechiae
Anterior chamber flare

questions.text: Which of the following is a sign of inflammatory activity in uveitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anterior chamber cells

 

Option B:

 

  • Anterior chamber cells are an indicator of inflammatory activity.
  • It is best assessed prior to pupillary dilatation because dilatation results in shedding of pigment cells into aqueous.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Keratic Precipitates: Keratic precipitates are deposits on the corneal endothelium. They can be a sign of previous or ongoing inflammation but are not necessarily an indicator of active inflammation, as they can persist after the inflammation has resolved.

 

Option C. Posterior Synechiae: Posterior synechiae, which are adhesions between the iris and the lens, are a result of inflammation but are not a direct sign of active inflammation. They indicate that inflammation has occurred in the past and can persist even after the active inflammation has resolved.

 

Option D. Anterior Chamber Flare: Anterior chamber flare, which is the presence of protein in the aqueous humor, indicates increased vascular permeability due to inflammation and is a sign of active inflammation in uveitis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most direct sign of active inflammatory activity in uveitis is Anterior Chamber Cells.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Necrotic melanoma
Endothelial cell melanoma
Spindle cell melanoma
Mixed cell melanoma

questions.text: The Modified Callender classification includes all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothelial cell melanoma

 

Option B:

 

 

 

The Modified Callender classification is a histopathological system used to classify uveal melanomas, particularly those involving the choroid and ciliary body. This classification is based on the predominant cell type found in the tumor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Necrotic Melanoma: While necrosis can be a feature within melanomas, the Modified Callender classification categorizes melanomas based on the type of viable tumor cells present, not on the presence of necrosis. Therefore, "necrotic melanoma" is not a category in this classification system.

 

Option C. Spindle Cell Melanoma: This is a category in the Modified Callender classification. Spindle cell melanomas are characterized by elongated cells with spindle-shaped nuclei and are generally considered to have a better prognosis than other types.

 

Option D. Mixed Cell Melanoma: This category is also included in the Modified Callender classification. Mixed cell melanomas contain a combination of cell types, typically both spindle and epithelioid cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The option that is not included in the Modified Callender classification Endothelial Cell Melanoma.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Severe acute anterior uveitis
Single episode of unilateral acute anterior uveitis
Bilateral acute anterior uveitis
Granulomatous uveitis

questions.text: Which of the following uveitis does not need further investigations?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single episode of unilateral acute anterior uveitis

 

Option B:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Severe Acute Anterior Uveitis: Severe acute anterior uveitis usually requires further investigation to determine its cause, especially if it's recurrent or associated with systemic symptoms. Investigations can help rule out systemic associations like HLA-B27 related conditions, infections, or other autoimmune diseases.

 

Option C. Bilateral Acute Anterior Uveitis: Bilateral acute anterior uveitis often warrants further investigation since it's more likely to be associated with systemic diseases such as sarcoidosis, HLA-B27 associated conditions, or infectious causes.

 

Option D. Granulomatous Uveitis: Granulomatous uveitis typically requires further investigations due to its association with systemic diseases like sarcoidosis, tuberculosis, syphilis, and others. Identifying the underlying cause is crucial for appropriate management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Single episode of unilateral acute anterior uveitis does not need further investigations.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: Dalen fuch nodules are present in retino choroidal periphery
B/L non-granulomatous uveitis
Retrolental flare is the earliest sign
Ciliary body is called the dangerous zone of the eye

questions.text: Identify the false statement about sympathetic ophthalmitis.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B/L non-granulomatous uveitis

 

Option B:

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a bilateral, granulomatous, non-suppurative panuveitis that occurs after penetrating injury to uvea in one eye. It results due to autoimmune reaction to uveal tissue.
  • Injured eye is called exciting eye and fellow eye is called sympathizing eye.
  • Dangerous zone of the eye – Ciliary body region
  • Usual time of onset of sympathetic ophthalmitis – 4-8 weeks after injury
  • Earliest symptoms of sympathetic ophthalmia in uninjured eye:
    • Difficulty in near vision (Due to loss of accommodation)
    • Photophobia
  • Earliest sign of sympathetic ophthalmia in uninjured eye—Retrolental flare
  • Dalen-Fuch’s nodules are seen. These are small, yellow white spots scattered throughout the fundus. These consist of epithelioid cells and are present between retinal pigmented epithelium and Bruch’s membrane.
  • Best time for enucleation of an injured eye to prevent sympathetic ophthalmia in uninjured eye- within 15 days.
  • Enucleation is contraindicated in panopthalmitis whereas evisceration is contraindicated in sympathetic ophthalmitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dalen-Fuchs Nodules Are Present in Retinochoroidal Periphery: This statement is true. Dalen-Fuchs nodules are characteristic of sympathetic ophthalmia and are found in the peripheral retina and choroid. They are aggregates of epithelioid cells and lymphocytes between Bruch's membrane and the retinal pigment epithelium.

 

 

Option C. Retrolental Flare is the Earliest Sign: Retrolental flare, or flare in the anterior vitreous, can be an early sign of sympathetic ophthalmia, indicating inflammation. However, it might not be the earliest or the most specific sign. Other early signs can include decreased vision and redness of the eye.

 

Option D. Ciliary Body is Called the Dangerous Zone of the Eye: This statement is true. The ciliary body is often referred to as the "dangerous zone" because trauma to this area is thought to increase the risk of developing sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The false statement about sympathetic ophthalmia is Bilateral Non-granulomatous Uveitis. The correct characterization should be bilateral granulomatous uveitis.

 

Ref: pg 437- ocular injuries/ 6th edition/ comprehensive ophthalmology ak khurana

choices.text: 10 to 20
40 to 50
70 to 80
> 100

questions.text: What is the total number of ciliary processes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 70 to 80

 

Option C:

 

The total number of ciliary processes is 70 to 80.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total number of ciliary processes is 70-80.

 

Ref: pg 67 / anatomy & physiology of eyeball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Surface ectoderm
Mesoderm
Neuro ectoderm
All of the above

questions.text: On visiting an Ophthalmologist for regular check-up, she uses 2% Homatropine drops are used to dilate the patient’s pupils by blocking the action of Sphincter pupillae muscle. What is the embryological origin of this muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuro ectoderm

 

Option C:

 

It originates from the part of the neuroectoderm that forms the optic cup, which eventually gives rise to the iris.

 

 

Explanation:

 

OPTION A. Surface Ectoderm: The surface ectoderm is responsible for forming the epidermis, hair, nails, and epithelium of the nose, mouth, and anal canal, as well as the lens of the eye. However, it does not give rise to any muscles.

 

OPTION B. Mesoderm: The mesoderm forms most of the musculoskeletal system, the circulatory system, and the excretory system. However, the muscles of the iris (which include the sphincter pupillae) are not derived from the mesoderm.

 

Option D. All of the Above: This option is incorrect because the sphincter pupillae muscle specifically originates from the neuroectoderm, not from the surface ectoderm or the mesoderm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sphincter pupillary are derived from Neuroectoderm.

 

Ref: pg 12/ COMPREHENSIVE ophthalmology/ 6th edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: MEDPOR
Hydroxyapatite
PMMA
Aluminium oxide

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient diagnosed with RE Right Eye pan ophthalmitis is planned for an evisceration procedure with orbital implants. Which among the following is non-porous?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PMMA

 

Option C:

 

PMMA (Polymethyl Methacrylate): PMMA is a non-porous, biocompatible synthetic polymer. It has been widely used in ophthalmology as a material for intraocular lenses and as an orbital implant. Its non-porous nature means it does not allow for tissue ingrowth, which can be a disadvantage in terms of implant stability and risk of extrusion.

 

Types of Orbital Implant:

 

There are four broad categories of orbital implant:

 

  1. Integrated
  2. Semi integrated
  3. Nonintegrated
  4. Dermis fat graft.

 

Integrated Implants: These implants are made of porous material, meaning tissues can grow into the implant. Examples are hydroxy-apatite (coral like), polyethylene (Medpor) and Aluminium oxide (Alumina).

 

A recent development is coated implants such as Bioeye, where the implant has a soft coating to which the muscles can be attached.

 

Advantages: excellent mobility; stays in the same position; rarely migrates; can be pegged.

Disadvantages: risk of infection and extrusion is higher than non integrated; expensive.

 

Semi Integrated Implants: These implants are not porous but have large gaps through which the muscles are pulled and tied. The Allen implant is the best known semi-integrated implant.

 

Advantages: Inexpensive; good mobility.

 

Disadvantages: risk of exposure is higher due to the irregular surface rubbing against the artificial eye.

 

Non-Integrated Implants: Made of acrylic, these implants are often encased in a capsule of tissue due to the body’s healing response. There is little or no contact with the muscles. An example is the acrylic ball implant.

 

Advantages: Inexpensive; very low risk of exposure.

 

Disadvantages: Less movement; can migrate within the orbit.

 

Dermis Fat Graft

 

The graft contains deep layers of skin and the fat below it, measuring about 2cm in length, width and depth.

 

Muscles cannot be attached to a fat graft.

 

There is no risk of rejection as this graft uses the patient’s own tissue. These grafts are often the best option when a material implant is exposed or infected.

 

Advantages: fat grafts grow with the child, matching growth of the other eye. Inexpensive; very low risk of exposure

 

Disadvantages: Less movement; when done in adulthood, they often shrink (atrophy) with time, with a less satisfactory cosmetic appearance.

 

 

Ref: https://www.aaojournal.org/article/S0161-6420(18)30564-5/pdf

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MEDPOR (Microporous High-Density Polyethylene): MEDPOR is a porous implant material commonly used in orbital reconstruction. Its porosity allows for tissue ingrowth, which can reduce the risk of implant migration and extrusion. MEDPOR's interconnected, open pore structure facilitates fibrovascular in-growth, leading to better integration with the host tissues.

 

Option B. Hydroxyapatite: Hydroxyapatite is a naturally occurring mineral form of calcium apatite. It is a porous material, often used as an orbital implant due to its biocompatibility and osteoconductive properties. The porosity of hydroxyapatite allows for tissue integration, making it less likely to be rejected or extruded.

 

Option D. Aluminium Oxide: Aluminium oxide, also known as alumina is porous and known for its high strength and biocompatibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

PMMA (Polymethyl Methacrylate) and Aluminium is non-porous material used in orbital implants. Students must be aware that orbital implants are made of porous and solid materials.

 

Ref: https://wechope.org/retinoblastoma/care/treatment/enucleation/types-of-implant/#Question level: Intermediate

choices.text: Pupillary margin
Collarette
Root of iris
Limbus

questions.text: Circulus arteriosus major is seen in which part of the eye?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Root of iris

 

Option C.

 

  • Circulus arteriosus major is located at the root of the iris.

  • It is formed by the anastomosis of long posterior ciliary arteries and anterior ciliary arteries.

  • Branches from circulus arteriosus major supply the ciliary process â€“ one branch for each process.

  • Several branches from the arterial circle run through iris towards pupillary margin and anastomose to form circulus arteriosus minor.

 

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option A. Pupillary Margin: it is the outer edge of the pupil. The pupillary ruff is the anterior termination of the posterior pigmented layer of the iris.

 

Option B. Collarette: The iris is divided into a pupillary zone and a ciliary zone by a circular ridge, located 1.5mm away from the pupillary margin, called the collarette.

 

IRIS CRYPTS: The anterior limiting layer lines the iris and is the anterior-most condensation of the iris stroma. It is absent in the areas of crypts.

 

Option D. Limbus: The limbus of the eye is the junction of the cornea and the sclera.

 

Functions of Limbus:

 

  1. Transition Zone: The limbus acts as a transition zone between the transparent cornea and the opaque sclera. This border is necessary for maintaining the structural and functional integrity of the eye.

  2. Stem Cell Reservoir: The limbus contains stem cells that are crucial for the regeneration and repair of corneal tissue. These limbal stem cells continuously replenish the corneal epithelium.

  3. Barrier Function: It serves as a barrier to prevent the conjunctival epithelial cells from migrating onto the corneal surface, which is important for preserving corneal clarity and vision.

  4. Nutrient and Waste Exchange: The limbus plays a role in the exchange of nutrients and waste materials between the cornea and the conjunctiva. This is vital for maintaining the health of the corneal cells.

  5. Vascular Supply: Although the cornea is avascular (lacking blood vessels) for transparency, the limbus contains blood vessels that supply nutrients to the peripheral cornea and aid in immune responses.

  6. Anatomical Markings: Clinically, the limbus is used as a landmark for various eye surgeries and procedures due to its distinct anatomical positioning.

 

The health and integrity of the limbus are essential for corneal health and overall visual acuity. Damage or disease affecting the limbal region can lead to serious ocular conditions, such as limbal stem cell deficiency, which can impair vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blood supply of the iris and the anterior segment of the eye is derived from the circulus arteriosus major which is formed by the anastomoses of the long posterior ciliary and anterior ciliary arteries.

 

Ref: Parsonâ€™s diseases of the eye 22nd edition

The ophthalmologist carried out a slit-lamp examination, wherein through a 1x1mm slit beam, around 20 cells were noted in the anterior chamber. What is the categorization under SUN group grading?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2+

 

Option B:

 

  • Aqueous cells are counted on oblique slit lamp illumination with a 1x1mm slit.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

As per SUN Group grading of aqueous cells, 2+ cells implies 16-12 cells / 1x1 mm slit.

 

Ref: KANSKI 9TH EDITION

choices.text: <50
<100
<150
<200

questions.text: The following image is seen on fundoscopy, what is the likely CD4 count (in cells/mm3) of the patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) <50

 

Option A.

 

  • The fundus picture is diagnostic of cytomegalovirus retinitis.
  • A perivascular yellow-white retinal lesion frequently associated with retinal hemorrhage or a focal white granular infiltrate, often without hemorrhage, can be observed. Both lesions enlarge in a progressively expanding “brushfire” pattern
  • Pizza-pie appearance – Hemorrhagic retinitis.
  • Usually occurs in immunocompromised patients.
  • Opportunistic infection in AIDS when CD4 count < 50 cells/mm3.
  • Patients with AIDS and CMV retinitis typically have minimal or no clinical vitritis or anterior chamber inflammation due to the underlying immunosuppressed state. Even though anterior chamber is clinically quiet, a cytokine-mediated inflammatory response pattern is actively present in the aqueous humor.
  • A response to HAART is defined as an increase in CD4+ T cell count of at least 50 cells/μL to a level of 100 cells/μL or more. 

 

Other Ocular Associations of HIV:

 

  1. HIV-Associated Retinopathy: One of the most common ocular manifestations of HIV is HIV-associated retinopathy. This condition affects the blood vessels in the retina and is more common in patients with advanced HIV infection. It can lead to vision problems, including blurred vision and loss of peripheral vision. Examination of the retina using ophthalmoscopy may reveal characteristic changes like cotton-wool spots and microaneurysms.
  2. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Retinitis: CMV is a common opportunistic infection in advanced HIV/AIDS. Patients with low CD4+ T-cell counts (<50/CMM) are at higher risk for CMV retinitis. Symptoms may include floaters, blurry vision, and scotomas (blind spots).
  3. Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus: HIV-infected individuals are at an increased risk of developing herpes zoster (shingles), including its ocular form, herpes zoster ophthalmicus. This condition can cause painful rashes around the eye and potentially lead to vision threatening complications due to corneal scarring and decompensation.
  4. Conjunctivitis and Dry Eye: HIV patients may experience recurrent or chronic conjunctivitis (inflammation of the conjunctiva) and dry eye syndrome. These symptoms can be bothersome and may require supportive care, such as artificial tears or topical medications.
  5. Kaposi's Sarcoma: It may present as reddish-purple lesions on the conjunctiva or other ocular structures.
  6. Opportunistic Infections: Other opportunistic infections, such as toxoplasmosis and fungal infections, can also affect the eyes in HIV patients, causing vision problems and eye discomfort.
  7. Immune Recovery Uveitis: Some HIV patients who start antiretroviral therapy (ART) may develop immune recovery uveitis as their immune system begins to recover. IRU is predominantly a posterior segment inflammatory disorder that results in decreased vision and floaters in the affected eye . It is currently one of the most common causes of new vision loss in patients with AIDS-related CMV retinitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CMV retinitis suggests CD count of <50

 

Ref: 1. Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

2. Urban B, Bakunowicz-Åazarczyk A, Michalczuk M. Immune recovery uveitis: pathogenesis, clinical symptoms, and treatment. Mediators Inflamm. 2014;2014:971417. doi: 10.1155/2014/971417. Epub 2014 Jun 24. PMID: 25089078; PMCID: PMC4096001.

choices.text: Photopsia
Metamorphopsia
Photophobia
Macropsia

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with choroiditis. Which of the following is not a symptom she could’ve had?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Photophobia

 

Option C:

 

Symptoms of choroiditis

 

  1. Defective vision
  2. Photopsia – due to irritation of photoreceptors
  3. Floaters – exudates in vitreous
  4. Metamorphopsia – altered retinal contour due to choroidal lesions
  5. Micropsia – due to separation of visual cells
  6. Macropsia – due to crowding of visual cells
  7. Positive scotoma

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Photopsia: Photopsia, or the perception of flashes of light, is a symptom commonly associated with retinal or choroidal diseases. Patients with choroiditis may experience photopsia due to the irritation or detachment of the retina.

 

Option B. Metamorphopsia: Metamorphopsia, a visual distortion where straight lines appear wavy or objects appear altered in size or shape, can occur in choroiditis if the macula, the central part of the retina, is affected.

 

Option D. Macropsia: Macropsia is a condition where objects appear larger than they actually are. It is typically associated with conditions affecting the macula of the retina. While possible, it's less commonly reported in choroiditis compared to other retinal conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptom least likely to be associated with choroiditis is C. Photophobia.

 

Ref: Khurana Comprehensive Ophthalmology 5th edition

choices.text: Long posterior ciliary arteries with short posterior ciliary arteries
Long posterior ciliary artery with anterior ciliary arteries
Short posterior ciliary arteries with anterior ciliary arteries
Short posterior ciliary artery with anterior conjunctival arteries

questions.text: Circulus arteriosus major is the anastomosis between:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Long posterior ciliary artery with anterior ciliary arteries

 

Option B:

 

 

CIRCULUS ARTERIOSUS MAJOR: anastomosis between anterior ciliary artery & long posterior ciliary artery.

 

CIRCULUS ARTERIOSUS MINOR: anastomosis between branches from the major arterial circle with each other near the pupil.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Long Posterior Ciliary Arteries with Short Posterior Ciliary Arteries: The long posterior ciliary arteries primarily supply the ciliary body and the choroid, while the short posterior ciliary arteries also contribute to the choroid's vascularization. However, these arteries do not primarily form the Circulus arteriosus major.

 

Option C. Short Posterior Ciliary Arteries with Anterior Ciliary Arteries: While both these sets of arteries play important roles in the ocular blood supply, they are not the primary contributors to the formation of the Circulus arteriosus major.

 

Option D. Short Posterior Ciliary Artery with Anterior Conjunctival Arteries: The short posterior ciliary arteries and anterior conjunctival arteries supply different parts of the eye and are not directly involved in forming the Circulus arteriosus major.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Circulus arteriosus major is the anastomosis between the long posterior ciliary arteries and the anterior ciliary arteries.

 

Ref: pg 69 / anatomy & physiology of eyeball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

choices.text: Iris
Ciliary body
Sclera
Pupil

questions.text: Suspensory ligaments of lens consists of fibres passing from the lens to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ciliary body

 

Option B:

 

  • Suspensory ligaments of lens (Zonules of Zinn) are also called ciliary zonules since they pass from the lens to ciliary body.
  • These hold the lens in position and enable the ciliary muscle to act on it.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. IRIS: There is no anatomical connection between iris and lens. Iris pigments can get deposited over lens capsule in cases of blunt ocular trauma called glaucomflecken.

 

In cases of uveitis, adhesions form between iris and lens called posterior synechiae.

 

Option C: SCLERA: Sclera is the outermost coat of the eye. In cases of aphakia, Intraocular lens can be implanted by suspending it from sclera. The technique is called sclera fixated IOL and can be glued or sutured.

 

Option D: Pupil: Pupil is the circular aperture through which light passes into the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suspensory ligaments are fibres passing from crystalline lens to ciliary body.

 

Ref: pg 180/ LENS / Comprehensive ophthalmology/ AK KHURANA/ 6th edition

choices.text: Stroma
Anterior pigmented epithelium
Posterior pigmented epithelium
Anterior limiting layer

questions.text: What does the definitive colour of the iris depend on?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anterior limiting layer

 

Option D:

 

The definitive colour of the iris depends on the anterior limiting layer.

 

  • Contains melanocytes & fibroblasts.
  • In brown iris, is thick & doubly pigmented.
  • In blue iris, this layer is thin and contains few pigmented cells.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stroma: The stroma of the iris contains loose connective tissue, blood vessels, and melanocytes.

 

Option B. Anterior Pigmented Epithelium: The anterior pigmented epithelium is a layer of the iris that lies behind the stroma. While it does contain pigment, it is not the primary determinant of the iris's visible color.

 

Option C. Posterior Pigmented Epithelium: The posterior pigmented epithelium, located on the back side of the iris, is heavily pigmented in all individuals, regardless of eye color. This layer prevents light from passing through the iris and is not directly involved in determining the visible color of the iris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The definitive color of the iris depends mostly on the anterior limiting membrane.

 

Ref: pg 65 / anatomy & physiology of eye ball /3rd edition/ AK KHURANA

2. Miller PE. Uvea. Slatter's Fundamentals of Veterinary Ophthalmology. 2008:203–29. doi: 10.1016/B978-072160561-6.50014-9. Epub 2009 Jun 5. PMCID: PMC7149650.
